item.description: An official Congress API, voter ID laws, local internet speeds, the Getty Provenance Index, and space weather.
item.content:encoded:
An official Congress API, voter ID laws, local internet speeds, the Getty Provenance Index, and space weather.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Welcome to the 300th(!) edition of Data Is Plural. To mark the occasion, Iâ€™ve published a bonus, self-referential, ultra-niche dataset of the newsletterâ€™s feedback-soliciting phrases.

Â 

Congress gets an official API. The United Statesâ€™ legislative branch now has an official API, the Library of Congress announced last week. It provides structured data on legislators, bills, bill summaries, amendments, committee reports, appointee nominations, international treaties, and more. To use the service, youâ€™ll need to sign up for a free API key. Read more: Some context from the Congressional Data Coalition. Related: The Government Publishing Officeâ€™s bulk data on bills and bill summaries (DIP 2020.08.26) and ProPublicaâ€™s Congress API. [h/t Jackie Kazil]

Â 

Voter ID laws. As part of his PhD research, Tom Barton has constructed a dataset of voter identification requirements around the world. For each country and US state, the dataset indicates the type of identification needed to vote (a photo ID, non-photo ID, or just basic personal details), how many forms of identification the voter must provide, and more. Related: A detailed examination of US voter ID laws from the National Conference of State Legislatures. Previously: Recent US voting legislation tracked by the Voting Rights Lab (DIP 2022.07.20).

Â 

Local internet speeds. If youâ€™ve tried measuring your internet speed, you might have used Ooklaâ€™s testing service. The company releases a series of quarterly datasets that summarize the test results, aggregated into geospatial tiles. (The tile sizes vary by latitude but measure roughly 2,000 feet by 2,000 feet at the equator.) For each tile, the datasets list the number of tests performed and devices tested, plus the average download speed, upload speed, and latency. As seen in: â€œEuropeâ€™s internet speeds are faster than ever, but not for everyoneâ€ (EDJNet) and associated dashboard. Previously: Internet speeds from the Measurement Lab (DIP 2019.05.22). [h/t Federico Caruso]

Â 

Art sales and ownership. The Getty Provenance Index contains more than 2.3 million historical records relating to the sale and ownership of artworks, searchable online by artist, owner, auction house, date, and other characteristics. As part of an ongoing project to remodel the index, the Getty Research Institute has also published a subset of the records as open data. The largest of those datasets describes more than 1 million sales in Europe from the 1600s to 1945. [h/t Richard E. Spear]

Â 

Space weather. NOAAâ€™s Space Weather Prediction Center keeps tabs on a variety of phenomena, such as coronal mass ejections, geomagnetic storms, and solar flares. The agencyâ€™s reports and datasets include three-day forecasts, sunspot predictions, solar wind observations, and more. The agency also provides dashboards for several audiences, such as the aviation community, emergency management, and â€œspace weather enthusiasts.â€ [h/t oblib]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.09.07 edition
item.description: LGBTQ+ rights, the General Social Survey, most buildings in Spain, battles and sieges, and even more street trees.
item.content:encoded:
LGBTQ+ rights, the General Social Survey, most buildings in Spain, battles and sieges, and even more street trees.

Â 

LGBTQ+ rights. Equaldex tracks LGBTQ+ rights around the world, categorizing the liberties and restrictions that relate to more than a dozen issues, such as same-sex marriage, blood donation, military service, employment discrimination, and the right to change oneâ€™s legal gender. The collaboratively-edited database provides an API to retrieve those categorizations and contextual notes by country and/or US state. The project also keeps tabs on developments that alter those rights and public opinion polling. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Five decades of US public opinion. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the General Social Survey, which calls itself â€œthe only full-probability, personal-interview survey designed to monitor changes in both social characteristics and attitudes currently being conducted in the United States.â€ It combines a â€œstandard core of demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal questionsâ€ with shorter-lived modules on topics such as religion, gun control, and mental health. You can explore the results online and also download the thoroughly documented, anonymized microdata. Related: The International Social Survey Program, co-founded by the GSS team.

Â 

Most buildings in Spain. The Spanish governmentâ€™s cadastral service provides geospatial data on every parcel, address, and building for â€œthe entire territory under its jurisdiction (the entire national territory except the Basque Country and Navarre).â€ The records, available to download programmatically, include each buildingâ€™s year of construction, total floor area, number of dwellings, and more. As seen in: â€œSpain lives in flats: why we have built our cities verticallyâ€ (El Diario, original in Spanish), and associated Twitter thread. [h/t Rose Mintzer-Sweeney]

Â 

Battles and sieges. Charles Miller and K. Shuvo Bakarâ€™s Historical Conflict Event Dataset covers 8,800+ military clashes spanning thousands of years, from Egyptâ€™s capture of Megiddo c. 1468 BC to the 2003 invasion of Iraq. The authors draw primarily from Tony Jaquesâ€™s Dictionary of Battles and Sieges, which they augment with additional research and sources. The resulting spreadsheet provides each eventâ€™s name, year, relevant war, narrative, participant list, location, and more. [h/t Micah Zenko]

Â 

Even more street trees. Dakota E. McCoy et al. have built a dataset of 5,000,000+ urban trees, gathered and harmonized from 63 US citiesâ€™ inventories. The level of detail differs by city, but can include the treeâ€™s species, date planted, location, height, trunk diameter, condition, and more. The authors also provide a range of summary statistics for each city. Previously: Street trees in DIP 2020.11.18, DIP 2018.08.08, and DIP 2016.11.16. [h/t Clayton Page Aldern]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.08.31 edition
item.description: Billion-dollar disasters, business formations, attempted repairs, Luftwaffe locations, and a fern tree of life.
item.content:encoded:
Billion-dollar disasters, business formations, attempted repairs, Luftwaffe locations, and a fern tree of life.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ A reader recently asked what criteria I use to evaluate datasets for DIP. Iâ€™ve received similar questions in the past, so I decided to write an FAQ-style public response, which you can find here. Itâ€™s a rough draft; feedback very much welcome.

Â 

Billion-dollar disasters. As â€œthe Nationâ€™s Scorekeeper in terms of addressing severe weather and climate events in their historical perspective,â€ the US National Centers for Environmental Information maintains an inventory of the most costly such disasters in the US â€”Â those that have caused at least $1 billion in estimated direct losses. The quarterly-updated dataset contains more than 330 severe storms, floods, droughts, wildfires, freezes, and other extreme events since 1980. You can download, filter, and sort the list (by disaster type, start/end dates, inflation-adjusted cost, and total deaths), as well as map, chart, and summarize it. [h/t Gary Price]

Â 

Business formations. To compile its Business Formation Statistics, the US Census Bureau analyzes several sources, including every application to the IRS for an Employer Identification Number (EIN) and those applicantsâ€™ first payroll tax filings. This allows the Bureau to provide monthly counts of business applications and formations by business type, industrial sector, and state. They also publish weekly datasets of application counts by state and an annual dataset that drills down to individual counties; both, however, lack business formation counts and other details found only in the monthly files. [h/t John C. Haltiwanger]

Â 

Attempted repairs. The Open Repair Alliance, â€œan international group of organisations committed to working towards a world where electrical and electronic products are more durable and easier to repair,â€ is developing an open standard for sharing data about those repairs. So far, theyâ€™ve gathered 62,000+ records from five partners. Each entry represents a repair session: its date and country, the productâ€™s brand and category, the repair status, a description of the problem, barriers to repair, and more.

Â 

Luftwaffe locations. Data scientist Sam Weiss has constructed a dataset tracking the World War II movements of the Luftwaffe, Nazi Germanyâ€™s air force. The information, scraped and geocoded from the Luftwaffe-history website ww2.dk, includes monthly locations and aggregate statistics (total size, additions, losses) by aircraft type and unit. Read more: A blog post and Twitter thread from Weiss.

Â 

Fern phylogenetics. Joel H. Nitta et al.â€™s Fern Tree of Life uses â€œa mostly automated, reproducible, open pipelineâ€ to convert fern DNA sequences from the National Institutes of Healthâ€™s GenBank into an interactive, browsable, and downloadable evolutionary tree. It currently covers 5,500+ species, from Abacopteris aspera to Zealandia vieillardii. [h/t Santiago RamÃ­rez Barahona]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.08.24 edition
item.description: Beneficial owners, administrative boundaries, legislative limits on teaching, Census tract population changes, and Bryanâ€™s whistle-stop tour.
item.content:encoded:
Beneficial owners, administrative boundaries, legislative limits on teaching, Census tract population changes, and Bryanâ€™s whistle-stop tour.

Â 

Beneficial owners. Open Ownership, a nonprofit aiming to improve â€œtransparency over who owns and controls companies,â€ works directly with countries to implement reforms and has developed a standard format for publishing such information. It also runs the Open Ownership Register, a database identifying the beneficial owners of 8.4 million companies so far, drawn primarily from records published by Denmark, Slovakia, the UK, and Ukraine. You can search, download, and query those records, which include the companiesâ€™ names, addresses, and other details, as well as the ownersâ€™ names, nationalities, and interests in those companies. [h/t Datasketch]

Â 

Administrative boundaries. The geoBoundaries project, maintained by the William & Mary geoLab and volunteer contributors since 2017, calls itself â€œthe worldâ€™s largest open, free and research-ready database of political administrative boundaries.â€ It provides an API and downloadable datasets of those boundaries at up to six levels per country, ranging from the entire nation to progressively smaller entities â€” outlining, for instance, approximately 650,000 villages in India and 2,900 Portuguese freguesias. Previously: The Database of Global Administrative Areas (DIP 2019.07.17) and national borders from 1886 to 2019 (DIP 2022.03.23).

Â 

Legislative limits on teaching. A PEN America report released last week examines recent developments in â€œeducational gag orders,â€ which it defines as â€œstate legislative efforts to restrict teaching about topics such as race, gender, American history, and LGBTQ+ identities in Kâ€“12 and higher education.â€ The study follows an initial report published in November 2021 and is supplemented by a weekly-updated spreadsheet that describes and tracks successful, failed, and pending bills since January 2021. [h/t Gary Price]

Â 

Census tract population changes. Researchers at the University of Tennessee have built a dataset and interactive map comparing each US Census tractâ€™s population in 2020 versus 2010. Because the Census Bureau routinely adds and modifies tracts between decennial surveys, the team used geographic â€œcrosswalkâ€ files from the National Historic Geographic Information System to make the comparisons. [h/t Tim Kuhn]

Â 

Bryanâ€™s whistle-stop tour. In 1896, Democratic Party presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan took four key campaign trips via rail, giving speeches in hundreds of cities along the way. The Railroads and the Making of Modern America project, based at the University of Nebraska, has compiled a table of those itineraries; it lists each eventâ€™s date and location and links to many of the speeches. As seen in: â€œDo Local Campaign Visits by a Populist Politician Matter in Elections?â€ (Johannes Buggle and Stephanos Vlachos).

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.08.17 edition
item.description: Recessions and expansions, consumer finances, pro-government militias, pollinationships, and atomic gardening.
item.content:encoded:
Recessions and expansions, consumer finances, pro-government militias, pollinationships, and atomic gardening.

Â 

Recessions and expansions. The US has no official definition of a recession, but many observers look to the non-governmental National Bureau of Economic Research, whose Business Cycle Dating Committee tries to determine â€œthe dates of peaks and troughs that frame economic recessions and expansions.â€ The committee publishes a table and data files listing those dates for dozens of cycles since the mid-1800s. But be prepared to wait: â€œOur determination of the trough date in April 2020 occurred 15 months after that date, in July 2021. Earlier determinations took between 4 and 21 months.â€ [h/t USAFacts]

Â 

Consumer finances. Every three years since 1983, the US Federal Reserve has conducted its Survey of Consumer Finances, which asks a sample of families detailed questions about their income, savings, assets, pensions, loans, credit lines, demographics, and more. â€œNo other study for the country collects comparable information,â€ according to the Fed. The most recent edition interviewed 5,783 families between May 2019 and April 2020. Related: Moritz Kuhn et al. (data available here) have merged results from the modern survey with those from an earlier incarnation conducted from 1948 to 1977. As seen in: â€œWealth of Two Nations: The U.S. Racial Wealth Gap, 1860-2020â€ (Ellora Derenoncourt et al.). [h/t Sharon Machlis]

Â 

Pro-government militias. Sabine Carey et al.â€™s Pro-Government Militias Database focuses on armed, organized groups that align themselves with a government but are not part of its official security forces. The latest version, published earlier this year and browsable online, provides a wide range of structured information about 504 such groups active between 1981 and 2014, including their purpose, membership, targets, government links, material support, and more.

Â 

Pollinationships. Nicholas Balfour et al.â€™s Database of Pollinator Interactions â€œdocuments British pollinator-plant associations,â€ bringing together records from â€œdisparate publications currently scattered throughout the scientific literatureâ€ (and other sources) into a queryable depository. Its 100,000+ entries document 320,000+ interactions observed between 1,800+ insect species and 1,200+ plant species, some published as early as 1895. [h/t Tyler Knight]

Â 

Atomic gardening. The Mutant Variety Database, jointly maintained by the International Atomic Energy Agency and the UNâ€™s Food and Agriculture Organization, tracks the metaphorical and literal fruits of atomic gardening, a decades-old practice also known as radiation breeding. The databaseâ€™s 3,400+ entries indicate each known varietyâ€™s crop type, species, targeted characteristics, mutation development method, country, registration year, and more. [h/t Lee Wilkins]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.08.10 edition
item.description: Young adult migration, social capital, CPUs and GPUs, trade in post-unification Italy, and Star Trek computer-talk.
item.content:encoded:
Young adult migration, social capital, CPUs and GPUs, trade in post-unification Italy, and Star Trek computer-talk.

Â 

Young adult migration. Researchers at Harvard University and the Census Bureau have linked federal tax filings, Census records, and other government data to track the migration patterns of young US residents. Specifically, for each person born in the US between 1984 and 1992, the researchers compared where they lived at age 16 to where they lived at age 26. The projectâ€™s public dataset counts the approximate number who moved to/from each pair of commuting zones â€” overall and disaggregated by race/ethnicity and parental income level. Read more: A reporting recipe from Brent Jones and Eric Schmid, who analyzed the data for St. Louis Public Radio.

Â 

Social capital. Using data on billions of Facebook connections and group memberships, Raj Chetty et al.â€™s Social Capital Atlas calculates three metrics for US counties, ZIP codes, high schools, and colleges: economic connectedness (friendships between low-income and high-income users), cohesiveness (how often usersâ€™ friends are also friends with one another), and civic engagement (membership in volunteer groups). Read more: The Upshot explores and explains the projectâ€™s findings. Previously: Measurements of social connectedness (DIP 2020.09.30) and economic mobility (DIP 2019.06.12), from some of the same researchers. [h/t Johannes Stroebel]

Â 

CPUs and GPUs. Yifan Sun et al., seeking to test Mooreâ€™s Law and Dennard scaling, â€œhave collected data for all CPU and GPU products (to our best knowledge) that have been released by Intel, AMD [...], and NVIDIA since January 1st, 2000.â€ The authorsâ€™ dataset and charting tool, describing 4,800+ processors through early 2021, uses information gathered from TechPowerUp, WikiChip, and company websites. They identify each productâ€™s vendor, release date, transistor count, base frequency, and other details. [h/t matt_d]

Â 

Trade in post-unification Italy. The Lost Highway project, a collaboration between researchers at four Italian universities, aims â€œto test a number of broad historical conjectures about the long term shortcomings of the Italian development path by collecting as much quantitative evidence as possible.â€ Their Bankit-FTV database provides annual import and export totals for 1862 to 1939, by product and trading partner, with 6,000+ product descriptions standardized into approximately 600 commodity groupings. [h/t Francesco Piccinelli Casagrande]

Â 

â€œTea, Earl Grey, hot.â€ Combing the full transcripts of Star Trek: The Next Generation, Benett Axtell and Cosmin Munteanu found more than 1,000 lines of dialogue between the showâ€™s characters and the starship Enterpriseâ€™s computer. Their dataset of these interactions lists each lineâ€™s phrasing, character, interaction type, stage directions, and more. [h/t Christian A. Gebhard + Sara Stoudt + Tidy Tuesday]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.08.03 edition
item.description: Employee benefit plans, European cropland, Christianity in China, data governance ratings, and diplomatic gifts.
item.content:encoded:
Employee benefit plans, European cropland, Christianity in China, data governance ratings, and diplomatic gifts.

Â 

Employee benefit plans. US companies that offer their employees a retirement plan, such as a pension or 401(k), must report the particulars of those plans through Form 5500 â€” a creation of the IRS, Department of Labor, and Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. Employers offering health plans, vacation, or other welfare benefits to 100+ workers must typically report those, too. The Department of Labor publishes datasets with details from all Form 5500 submissions going back to 1999, as well as a search tool that goes back to 2010. Related: Through a FOIA request, Dan Bauman has obtained decades of metadata on 80,000+ â€œtop hatâ€ statements, which concern plans â€œproviding deferred compensation for a select group of management or highly compensated employees.â€ [h/t Vincent Cocula]

Â 

European cropland. Maja Schneider et al.â€™s EuroCrops project combines â€œall publicly available self-declared crop reporting datasets from countries of the European Union.â€ So far, that universe corresponds to the entirety or parts of 16 countries. The projectâ€™s datasets include various attributes from the original data files, geographic coordinates for each agricultural parcel, and each parcelâ€™s primary crop type, which the authors have standardized using a taxonomy they devised.

Â 

Christianity in China. The China Historical Christian Database, a project based at Boston Universityâ€™s School of Theology, spans the years 1550 to 1950. Launched last week, it provides â€œtools to discover where every Christian church, school, hospital, orphanage, publishing house, and the like were located in China,â€ plus â€œwho worked inside those buildings, both foreign and Chinese.â€ The database, available to download and explore online, describes 33,000+ people, 7,000+ organizations, the relationships between those entities, and more.

Â 

Data governance ratings. A new report from George Washington Universityâ€™s Digital Trade and Data Governance Hub rates 68 countries on their approaches to data governance. It scores each country on 26 indicators across 6 categories â€” for instance, whether it has a personal data protection law, publishes an open data portal, and/or says it adheres to the OECD AI Principles. Previously: The Global Data Barometer (DIP 2022.05.18). [h/t Susan Ariel Aaronson]

Â 

Diplomatic gifts. Federal employees are not supposed to accept major gifts from foreign governments. But exceptions occur, such as â€œwhen it appears that to refuse the gift would likely cause offense or embarrassment,â€ and agencies must annually report those exceptions in the Federal Register. In 2020, Alex Cookson fetched and parsed those reports, yielding information (donor name and country, recipient name and agency, gift description and value) on 8,300+ gifts from 1999 to 2018. Previously: Congressional â€œgift travelâ€ (DIP 2016.04.27).

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.07.27 edition
item.description: Wildfires around the world, hospital price lists, monkeypox strains, startup factories, and shark incidents.
item.content:encoded:
Wildfires around the world, hospital price lists, monkeypox strains, startup factories, and shark incidents.

Â 

Wildfires around the world. The Global Wildfire Information System, expanding on the work of European Forest Fire Information System, uses satellite data to provide weekly and annual estimates of the number of fires and area burned in 200+ countries. Its bulk data indicates monthly burned hectares by country, sub-country unit, and land type from 2002 to 2019, as well as the boundaries of individual fires from 2001 to 2020. It also publishes gridded spatial data relating to fire danger forecasts, active fires, emissions, and more. As seen in: El Diarioâ€™s analysis of forest fires in Spain. [h/t Olaya ArgÃ¼eso PÃ©rez]

Â 

Hospital price lists. Since January 2021, the US government has required hospitals to publish machine-readable files listing the standard charges for all items and services they provide. But thereâ€™s no standard format for these price lists (also known as â€œchargemastersâ€), no official central repository of them, and compliance has been lacking. Seeing those problems, the versioned-data platform DoltHub earlier this year ran a paid crowdsourcing campaign that pulled nearly 300 million prices from the published lists of roughly 1,800 hospitals into a single database. Related: Thanks to an earlier price transparency rule, California posts chargemasters for hundreds of hospitals, with records going back to 2011.

Â 

Monkeypox strains. Nextstrain, â€œan open-source project to harness the scientific and public health potential of pathogen genome data,â€ has begun analyzing genetic sequences from hundreds of monkeypox virus samples, the vast majority from infections in the past few months. The project provides metadata on each sample, including the date, country, variant, and mutation metrics, as well as detailed sequencing data from NCBI Virus. Previously: Coronavirus variant data from outbreak.info (DIP 2021.03.10). [h/t Karsten Johansson]

Â 

Startup factories. Venture studios are firms that build and launch startups. Jim Moranâ€™s Venture Studio Index tracks 260+ of them, plus 1,200+ of the startups theyâ€™ve launched. The dataset, â€œcollected manually by a team of researchers familiar with venture capital and the technology startup ecosystem,â€ includes founding years, locations, employee counts, relevant URLs, and more.

Â 

Shark bites. Madeline Riley et al. describe the Australian Shark-Incident Database, which contains details about 1,100+ shark bites (and attempted shark bites) between 1791 and early 2022, gathered by the Taronga Conservation Society using â€œquestionnaires provided to shark-bite victims or witnesses, media reports,â€ and information from state agencies. Read more: â€œNew dataset shows shark bites in Australia are increasing and researchers want to know whyâ€ (The Guardian).

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.07.20 edition
item.description: New voting laws, notable people, budget apportionments, digital trade provisions, and the World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
New voting laws, notable people, budget apportionments, digital trade provisions, and the World Cup.

Â 

New voting laws. The Voting Rights Lab has been tracking 2,000+ laws proposed in US state legislatures since 2021. The tracker focuses on â€œ12 major issue areas relating to voter access and representation,â€ such as early voting, same-day registration, and ID requirements. It lists each billâ€™s state, number, author, date introduced, current status, and issue areas, plus a summary and the labâ€™s â€œassessment of whether the legislation is likely to improve or interfere with voter access or the administration of elections.â€ As seen in: â€œHas Your State Made It Harder To Vote?â€ (FiveThirtyEight) Related: States Newsroomâ€™s Kira Lerner has compiled a spreadsheet of 120 new election-related criminal penalties, based partly on the trackerâ€™s data.

Â 

Notable people. â€œA new strand of literature aims at building the most comprehensive and accurate database of notable individuals,â€ observe Morgane Laouenan et al., who contribute a â€œcross-verified database of 2.29 million individualsâ€ mined from Wikidata and the English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese and Swedish editions of Wikipedia. For each person, the dataset provides their birth and death dates, gender, citizenship, occupations, and other details. Previously: The MIT-based Pantheon dataset (DIP 2016.02.03), also based on Wikipedia and since updated. [h/t Philip Jung]

Â 

Budget apportionments. Congress, through a process called appropriations, chooses how much money goes to each US federal agency and program. But the Office of Management and Budget, through a process called apportionment, ultimately sets the rules for spending those funds, â€œtypically limit[ing] the obligations [an agency] may incur for specified time periods, programs, activities, projects, objects, or any combination thereof.â€ Those binding decisions have generally not been available to the public â€” until last week, when OMB launched a database of apportionments for FY 2022, per a requirement in Congressâ€™s 2022 spending bill. [h/t Caitlin Emma]

Â 

Digital trade provisions. Mira Burri et al.â€™s TAPED dataset, which â€œseeks to comprehensively trace developments in the area of digital trade governance,â€ categorizes 100+ relevant aspects of 300+ preferential trade agreements signed since 2000. The dataset indicates, for instance, that the Peru-Australia Free Trade Agreement contains binding agreements on personal data protection, nonbinding language on cybersecurity, and no provisions regarding net neutrality.

Â 

The World Cup. Josh Fjelstulâ€™s World Cup Database, published this month, provides â€œextensively cleaned and cross-validatedâ€ information about each of the 21 FIFA World Cup tournaments played so far. Its 27 tables contain â€œapproximately 1.1 million data pointsâ€ regarding the teams that participated, their players and managers, the referees, match outcomes, goals, penalties, and more.

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.07.13 edition
item.description: Heat metrics, technology adoption, a pile of law, digital payments in India, and early movie theaters in Oregon.
item.content:encoded:
Heat metrics, technology adoption, a pile of law, digital payments in India, and early movie theaters in Oregon.

Â 

Heat metrics. When you talk about outdoor heat, youâ€™re likely referring to â€œdry-bulbâ€ temperatures, measured by a thermometer shielded from the sun and moisture. But other factors also contribute to the physiological experience of hot weather. To that end, Keith R. Spangler et al. have created a dataset containing daily estimates of the wet-bulb globe temperature, Universal Thermal Climate Index, heat index, humidex, and other heat metrics for every county in the contiguous United States from 2000 through 2020. That first metric, for instance, was â€œoriginally developed in the 1950s to establish epidemiologically relevant thermal thresholds to prevent heat-related illnesses at US military training camps,â€ and takes humidity, solar radiation, and wind speed into account.

Â 

Technology adoption. Diego A. Comin and Bart Hobijnâ€™s Cross-country Historical Adoption of Technology dataset, published in 2009, compiles statistics â€œon the adoption of over 100 technologies in more than 150 countries since 1800.â€ Examples include the number of telegrams sent, television sets in use, knee replacement surgeries performed, and metric tons of freight carried on railways. Last month, Charles Kenny and George Yang published a dataset and accompanying working paper that updates those numbers and expands the technologies covered. [h/t Ranil Dissanayake]

Â 

Legal language. Peter Henderson et al.â€™s Pile of Law is â€œa 256GB (and growing) dataset of open-source English-language legal and administrative data, covering court opinions, contracts, administrative rules, and legislative records.â€ Its texts come from CourtListener (DIP 2016.04.13), the Constitute Project (DIP 2022.04.13), the European Court of Human Rightsâ€™ published opinions, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureauâ€™s collection of credit card agreements, and many other sources. [h/t Lynn Cherny]

Â 

Digital payments in India. PhonePe, a digital payments company serving India, publishes quarterly aggregated data on users and transactions. The statistics, which go back to 2018 and power an interactive map, are available on a national, state, and district level. User counts are provided as totals, as well as grouped by device brand. Transactions are measured by count and total value, with the counts also disaggregated into a few categories.
